issues.title: "Invite code" does not seem consistent with industry norms
issues.author: rohan-wire
issues.body:
Hi,
I think "Invite code" is being used to describe two things which are very different and combining these does not conceptually reflect industry or user expectations.

1) There are things that you can use to find or join a room/chat. I call these join link or joining links. I would propose **invite link** or **join link**.

2) There are passwords or codes which are entered or scanned once you reach a particular screen. I would call this a **join password or code**

A QR code can encode either of these two things.

issues.title: To discuss: Owning Server
issues.author: turt2live
issues.body:
**Owning Server**: The specific server responsible for applying access control to a chat. When the system requires more than one (or all) servers to apply access control, there is no owning server. The owning server will typically be the hub server for a chat. This should NOT be shortened to "owner" to avoid confusion with other definitions in this document.

----

From https://github.com/turt2live/ietf-mimi-terminology/pull/3/commits/558c5523afcef756b94af0170e2daf380a3c32c7

issues.title: To discuss: Server Owner
issues.author: turt2live
issues.body:
**Server Owner**: The entity or person responsible for administrative function of the server, such as creating user accounts, banning/blocking chats, etc. This should NOT be shortened to "owner" to avoid confusion with other definitions in this document.

----

From https://github.com/turt2live/ietf-mimi-terminology/pull/3/commits/558c5523afcef756b94af0170e2daf380a3c32c7

issues.title: To discuss: Server Operator
issues.author: turt2live
issues.body:
**Server Operator**: The entity or person responsible for uptime and availability of a given server. This is typically the same as the server owner, though servers may be deployed to a shared hosting environment. The hosting provider becomes the server operator while the account holder with that provider becomes the server owner.

----

From https://github.com/turt2live/ietf-mimi-terminology/pull/3/commits/558c5523afcef756b94af0170e2daf380a3c32c7

comments.author: turt2live
comments.body: It's fairly unlikely that hosting providers for MIMI implementations/transports will sprout up (it just doesn't make sense), but it feels distinct enough from server owners to be worth writing down.

issues.title: To discuss: Chat Owner
issues.author: turt2live
issues.body:
**Chat Owners**: Users in a chat with superuser-like or above-admin permissions. Not all systems support this concept, instead only going as high as admin permissions. This should NOT be shortened to "owner" to avoid confusion with other definitions in this document.

----

From https://github.com/turt2live/ietf-mimi-terminology/pull/3/commits/558c5523afcef756b94af0170e2daf380a3c32c7

comments.author: coopdanger
comments.body:
As I've thought about this, I wonder if at this point we need only the definition of hub server. Are you using the server owner and server operator definitions anywhere? If not, I think defining them creates confusion and we can avoid it by not defining them.

Regarding owning server, I think we can defer trying to write a definition until we've had a detailed discussion about how the authorization policy for a chat is going to be decided between the participating providers and their servers.

comments.author: coopdanger

pulls.title: Remove incorrect description of MLS distribution service
pulls.author: rohan-wire
pulls.body: The definition Server had an incorrect statement about the MLS Distribution Service (DS). It is unnecessary. The MLS DS in the MIMI context includes the Servers of **all** the providers in an chat/MLS group and **part of all the clients**.

comments.body:
the diff is just slightly too narrow for me to suggest a diff, but I think it'd be good to clarify the DS somewhere in this document. We can also drop the p2p clause while we're here, given MIMI has largely agreed that it's not a thing the WG wants to pursue.

Suggested definition would be:

> **Server**: Responsible for routing events to other servers and local clients. The collection 
> of servers and clients in a chat form the MLS Delivery Service (DS).

I don't object to your rewording, but in general I find the DS term to be so unhelpful and counterintuitive that I prefer to only mention it only briefly in the transport protocol and ignore everywhere else.
Fair. We should move the DS definition to the working group's transport document when it has one.

pulls.title: Update terms decided in design team
pulls.author: rohan-wire
pulls.body:
Discussed in design team:
- Chat -> Room
- room members -> room participants
- Invite link -> join link. Clarified that a join link is machine-readable way to join. Retained Invite for the overall desired action.

Rohan just trying to make things clearer:
- Removed Opponent User (referred to "other users")

- I also made a small change to the definition of Kick, to preserve the ability for a moderator to do rude things even if they are not an active participant in the room.
